div1.p: Marie Gorgas thanks Kean for his informative letter. She is currently collaborating with Hendrick on a biography of Gorgas.

div1.head: Letter from Marie D. Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 5, 1924
div1.p:
It gave me so much
pleasure to have your letter and to have
you write so fully. It may be too late
to use much of it in the first book
but I am already at work on a
book of letters etc. and any thing from
you will be of value.

General Gorgas was always
your friend. He was interested in
your career. I find some letters
which show this in his files.

I am writing in haste as I
am just about to start on a trip
to Havana - where I am to be the
guest of honor of the Department
of Sanitation. Later I shall be
at the American Embassy. It
will be a wonderful experience
to see this place again and [?]
me. The past dramatic and with
results of transcendant importance.

Two articles have already
come out in this February and March
number of the World's Work. The biography
itself, of course will be more complete.
The abbreviation is for magazine
purposes. Mr. Burton J. Hendrick
who is collaborating with me in this
biography will be interested in your
letter.
Pardon this hasty note. Many thanks
div1.closer:
Sincerely. Marie A Gorgas. (over)
March 5th7
124
Ac
M
Mrs Walter Reed is now getting a
pension of $ 15000 a month - and I presume
Mrs Lazear is too. A little over a
year ago this same pension was
granted to me. Originally Mrs Reed's
pension was 12500 per month.
